faq.q1: How do I format Morse code input?
faq.a1: Separate each letter with a space. Use / for word spaces. Example: "... --- ..." for SOS.
faq.q2: What if I make a mistake?
faq.a2: Invalid Morse code patterns will be skipped. Make sure dots and dashes are separated by spaces.
faq.a3: Yes! The tool decodes numbers 0-9 from their Morse code patterns.
faq.a4: Use a forward slash (/) to separate words in Morse code.
faq.a5: Yes! Completely free with no limits. All processing happens in your browser for privacy.

faq.a1: The tool reverses the order of characters in your text. The last character becomes first, second-to-last becomes second, and so on.
faq.a2: Yes! All characters including spaces, punctuation, and special characters are preserved and reversed in order.
faq.a3: Yes! Simply paste the reversed text back into the input and reverse it again to get the original text.
faq.a4: Palindromes are words or phrases that read the same forwards and backwards, like "racecar" or "madam". Use this tool to test them!
faq.a5: Yes! Completely free with no limits. All processing happens in your browser for privacy and speed.

faq.a1: Morse code is a method of encoding text using dots (.) and dashes (-) to represent letters and numbers. It was invented in the 1830s for telegraph communication.
faq.q2: What does SOS mean in Morse code?
faq.a2: SOS is ... --- ... (three dots, three dashes, three dots). It's the international distress signal.
faq.a3: Yes! The tool supports numbers 0-9, each with its own Morse code pattern.
faq.q4: Is Morse code still used today?
faq.a4: Yes! It's still used in aviation, maritime communication, amateur radio, and as an accessibility tool.
faq.a5: Yes! Completely free with no limits. All processing happens in your browser for privacy.
